headline: Delta Takes $200 Million Hit Due to November Flight Cancellations
content: CompaniesDelta Takes $200 Million Hit Due to November Flight CancellationsDelta’s operations were heavily impacted during the shutdown, according to the company’s CEO.00CopyFacebookXTruthGettrLinkedInTelegramEmailSavePrintAir traffic controllers monitor planes at Los Angeles International Airport in Los Angeles on July 1, 2025. John Fredricks/The Epoch TimesRob Sabo12/3/2025|Updated: 12/3/20250:00X 1Alongside strong customer demand for the fourth quarter of 2025 and a positive outlook for the first half of 2026, Delta Air Lines reported in regulatory filings on Dec. 3 that it lost $200 million in pre-tax profits due to the longest government shutdown in U.S. history.The government shutdown began at midnight on Sept. 30 and lasted 43 days—a six-week span in which air traffic controllers worked without pay. Lengthy flight delays became common as the shutdown dragged on, and on Nov. 6, Federal Aviation Administration Administrator Bryan Bedford and Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy announced a 10 percent reduction in domestic flights at 40 of the country’s busiest airports.We had a problem loading this article. Please enable javascript or use a different browser. If the issue persists, please visit our help center.Share this articleLeave a commentRob SaboAuthorRob Sabo has worked as a business journalist for nearly two decades and covers a broad range of business topics for The Epoch Times.Author’s Selected ArticlesRivian Recalls Nearly 35,000 Delivery Vans Over Seat Belt Misuse IssueDec 03, 2025Apartment Rents Fall in November for 4th Month as Vacancy Rate Hits Record HighDec 02, 2025Costco Sues for Refunds Before Supreme Court Rules on Tariff LegalityDec 02, 2025Texas AG Opens Investigation Into Shein for Labor, Product ViolationsDec 01, 2025

headline: IRS, Treasury Issue Guidance on Trump Accounts
content: US NewsIRS, Treasury Issue Guidance on Trump AccountsFive types of contributions can be made to a child’s IRA account until the child turns 18.00CopyFacebookXTruthGettrLinkedInTelegramEmailSavePrintThe Internal Revenue Service building in Washington on March 10, 2025. Madalina Vasiliu/The Epoch TimesNaveen AthrappullyReporter12/3/2025|Updated: 12/3/20250:00X 1The IRS and Treasury Department have issued guidance on Trump accounts, a new type of individual retirement account (IRA) for children, the IRS said in a Dec. 2 statement.The tax-advantaged Invest America accounts, commonly referred to as “Trump accounts,” were established under the One Big Beautiful Bill Act signed into law by President Donald Trump in July. The plan aims to provide every newborn child with a “head start toward lifelong financial security and the American Dream,” the White House said in a Dec. 2 statement.We had a problem loading this article. Please enable javascript or use a different browser. If the issue persists, please visit our help center.Share this articleLeave a commentNaveen AthrappullyReporterNaveen Athrappully is a news reporter covering business and world events at The Epoch Times. headline: Trump Gives Most Direct Endorsement for Abolishing Federal Income Tax
content: Executive BranchTrump Gives Most Direct Endorsement for Abolishing Federal Income TaxThe president made the comments during a meeting with his Cabinet members on Tuesday.00CopyFacebookXTruthGettrLinkedInTelegramEmailSavePrintPresident Donald Trump makes an announcement from the Oval Office of the White House on Dec. 3, 2025. Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP via Getty ImagesJack PhillipsBreaking News Reporter12/3/2025|Updated: 12/3/20250:00X 1President Donald Trump on Tuesday provided his most direct endorsement yet that he believes his tariff policies would generate enough revenue to abolish federal income taxes.Trump told reporters in a Cabinet meeting that “at some point in the not too distant future you won’t even have income tax to pay” due to revenue produced by his administration’s tariffs.We had a problem loading this article. Please enable javascript or use a different browser. If the issue persists, please visit our help center.Share this articleLeave a commentJack PhillipsBreaking News ReporterJack Phillips is a breaking news reporter who covers a range of topics, including politics, U.S., and health news. A father of two, Jack grew up in California's Central Valley. headline: Apartment Rents Fall in November for 4th Month as Vacancy Rate Hits Record High
content: US Real EstateApartment Rents Fall in November for 4th Month as Vacancy Rate Hits Record HighA surplus of multifamily housing units pushed the national vacancy rate to 7.2 percent in November, according to a rental report.00CopyFacebookXTruthGettrLinkedInTelegramEmailSavePrintAn 'Apartment For Rent' sign displayed on a residential street. ShutterstockRob Sabo12/2/2025|Updated: 12/2/20250:00X 1An oversupply of multifamily housing units continues to bring down national apartment rental rates, which declined for the fourth consecutive month in November.Median rents across all multifamily property types for the month stood at $1,367, according to a national rental report published on Dec. 1 by Apartment List. Rental rates were down 1.1 percent from the same period a year earlier, and they’ve declined more than 5 percent from their peak of $1,442 in 2022, the report noted.We had a problem loading this article. Please enable javascript or use a different browser. headline: Changes Are Coming Soon at the Fed
content: EconomyChanges Are Coming Soon at the FedOverall, as you look around the world, the U.S. is the only major economy that is actually growing.00CopyFacebookXTruthGettrLinkedInTelegramEmailSavePrintKevin Hassett, director of the White House National Economic Council, walks toward the West Wing at the White House on June 30, 2025. Hassett said Beijing continues to fall short of its commitments on rare-earth shipments, despite recent increases. Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP via Getty ImagesLouis Navellier12/2/2025|Updated: 12/2/20250:00X 1CommentaryThe stock market reverted to its seasonal pattern by closing November up, with the major indexes rising between 3% and 5% last week. This big bounce was fueled by the rising odds for a December 10th key interest rate cut, especially after Fed Governors Mary Daly, Stephen Miran, Christopher Waller, and John Williams all spoke out in favor of a December rate cut due to labor market weakness. Some other Fed officials remain more cautious, such as Boston’s Susan Collins and Chicago’s Austan Goolsbee, but the New York Fed President John Williams has major influence with the Board to cut rates on December 10th.We had a problem loading this article. Please enable javascript or use a different browser. If the issue persists, please visit our help center.Share this articleLeave a commentLouis NavellierAuthorLouis Navellier is chairman and founder of Navellier & Associates in Reno, Nevada, which manages approximately $1 billion in assets. One of Wall Street’s renowned growth investors, Navellier writes five investment newsletters focused on growth investing. In addition to appearing on Bloomberg, Fox News, and CNBC giving his market outlook and analysis, he has been featured in Barron’s, Forbes, Fortune, Investor’s Business Daily, Money, Smart Money, and The Wall Street Journal.websiteAuthor’s Selected ArticlesThe Bears Send Some Tech Super-Stocks Down...TemporarilyNov 11, 2025The President Forges More Trade Deals in AsiaNov 04, 2025Spectacular Earnings Lift the Market to New HighsOct 28, 2025The Trade War With China Mutes the Market’s MomentumOct 21, 2025

headline: Americans Spent $44 Billion Online Over Holiday Stretch, Adobe Reports
content: EconomyAmericans Spent $44 Billion Online Over Holiday Stretch, Adobe Reports‘If there’s going to be a consumer spending pullback, it’s probably going to wait until 2026,’ says Bankrate analyst Ted Rossman.00CopyFacebookXTruthGettrLinkedInTelegramEmailSavePrintShoppers on Black Friday at a mall in Bethesda, Md., on Nov. 28, 2025. Madalina Kilroy/The Epoch TimesAndrew Moran12/2/2025|Updated: 12/2/20250:00X 1Americans turned on their mobile devices and desktop computers and spent more than expected during the key five-day Thanksgiving weekend shopping period, new data from Adobe Analytics show.Despite economic uncertainty and weaker sentiment, shoppers spent $14.25 billion on Cyber Monday, purchasing a wide range of items, from home furnishings to groceries. They also spent a record $11.8 billion online on Black Friday.We had a problem loading this article. Please enable javascript or use a different browser. If the issue persists, please visit our help center.Share this articleLeave a commentAndrew MoranAuthorAndrew Moran has been writing about business, economics, and finance for more than a decade. headline: US Drivers See Relief as Gas Prices Dip Below $3
content: EnergyUS Drivers See Relief as Gas Prices Dip Below $3Lower gasoline prices could be the new norm for another year, market experts say.00CopyFacebookXTruthGettrLinkedInTelegramEmailSavePrintA man puts gas at a gas station in Elkridge, Md. Madalina Kilroy/The Epoch TimesAndrew Moran12/2/2025|Updated: 12/2/20250:00X 1U.S. gasoline prices dropped below $3 per gallon for the first time in more than four years, according to the American Automobile Association.As of Dec. 2, the national average for a gallon of gas was $2.998—the lowest since May 2021. Pump prices have also fallen about six cents in the past week and are down from a year ago.We had a problem loading this article. Please enable javascript or use a different browser. headline: US Economy Outperforms on Back of Tech Investment Boom, OECD Says
content: EconomyUS Economy Outperforms on Back of Tech Investment Boom, OECD SaysThe OECD said the United States is outperforming other advanced economies largely because of exceptionally strong investment in ICT and AI.00CopyFacebookXTruthGettrLinkedInTelegramEmailSavePrintA construction crew works on a CloudHQ data center in Ashburn, Va., on July 17, 2024. Nathan Howard/Getty ImagesTom OzimekReporter12/2/2025|Updated: 12/2/20250:00X 1The U.S. economy is outperforming earlier expectations this year as surging tech sector investment and a rush of pre-tariff imports bolstered activity, helping offset the drag from cooling job growth and moderating household spending, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) said on Dec. 2 as it raised its U.S. growth forecast.In its latest Economic Outlook report issued on Dec. 2, the 38-country group said it now expects the U.S. economy to grow by 2 percent in 2025, up from the 1.6 percent it projected in June.We had a problem loading this article. Please enable javascript or use a different browser. If the issue persists, please visit our help center.Share this articleLeave a commentTom OzimekReporterTom Ozimek is a senior reporter for The Epoch Times. headline: Costco Sues for Refunds Before Supreme Court Rules on Tariff Legality
content: CompaniesCostco Sues for Refunds Before Supreme Court Rules on Tariff LegalityThe retail giant’s complaint requests a complete refund of duties it has already paid if the Supreme Court decides that the tariffs are unlawful.00CopyFacebookXTruthGettrLinkedInTelegramEmailSavePrintA Costco Wholesale warehouse sign is seen outside of a store in Silver Spring, Md., on Aug. 5, 2023. Mandel Ngan/AFP via Getty ImagesRob Sabo12/2/2025|Updated: 12/2/20250:00X 1Retail giant Costco Wholesale Corporation filed a lawsuit against the U.S. government on Nov. 28 in an effort to lay the groundwork for refunds of tariffs collected since President Donald Trump enacted global tariff policies under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA).The complaint filed in the U.S. Court of International Trade in Manhattan argued that the president’s invocation of the act beginning in February illegally imposed tariffs on goods imported from Mexico, Canada, and China. Trump has said that tariffs were justified as a matter of national emergency because of the amount of fentanyl making its way into the United States from those countries, and that the global levies are a necessary tool to negotiate trade deals that level the playing field between the United States and key global trade partners.We had a problem loading this article. Please enable javascript or use a different browser. If the issue persists, please visit our help center.Share this articleLeave a commentRob SaboAuthorRob Sabo has worked as a business journalist for nearly two decades and covers a broad range of business topics for The Epoch Times.Author’s Selected ArticlesRivian Recalls Nearly 35,000 Delivery Vans Over Seat Belt Misuse IssueDec 03, 2025Delta Takes $200 Million Hit Due to November Flight CancellationsDec 03, 2025Apartment Rents Fall in November for 4th Month as Vacancy Rate Hits Record HighDec 02, 2025Texas AG Opens Investigation Into Shein for Labor, Product ViolationsDec 01, 2025

headline: US Lowers Tariffs on South Korean Cars to 15 Percent
content: TariffsUS Lowers Tariffs on South Korean Cars to 15 PercentShares of Korean car companies rose on the announcement, which followed South Korea’s move to codify into law its investment commitments to the United States.00CopyFacebookXTruthGettrLinkedInTelegramEmailSavePrintNew Hyundai cars are displayed on the sales lot at a dealership in San Leandro, Calif., on May 30, 2023. Justin Sullivan/Getty ImagesAndrew Moran12/1/2025|Updated: 12/2/20250:00X 1The U.S. tariff on South Korean automobiles will be lowered to 15 percent retroactively to Nov. 1, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said.In a Dec. 1 statement posted on X, Lutnick said the White House will also remove import duties on airplane parts and “unstack” South Korea’s reciprocal tariff rate to match Japan and the European Union.We had a problem loading this article.
